Comment 4 by **ikarienator**: 
The maximum integer can be presented by float32 is indeed (1- 1**(-24))*2**128 - 1. I
agree.

Here is what I tried:
> fmt.Println(float32(340282356779733642748073463979561713664))
0 // stalls go 1.2.2 compiler and the go playground gives "[process took too long]".
> fmt.Println(float32(340282356779733642748073463979561713663))
3.4028235e+38
 
Note that they are both much bigger than the maximum range and no errors are raised.
